citation.article-title: Pseudonocardia eucalypti sp. nov., an endophytic actinobacterium with a unique knobby spore surface, isolated from roots of a native Australian eucalyptus tree
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pseudonocardia eucalypti sp. nov.
Pseudonocardia eucalypti (eu.ca.lyp′ti. N.L. gen. n. eucalypti of Eucalyptus, isolated from Eucalyptus microcarpa).
Cells are aerobic, Gram-reaction-positive, non-acid/alcohol-fast and catalase- and urease-positive.
Grows at 15–37 °C and pH 5–10 (weakly at 37 °C and pH 5).
Aerial mycelia are white on ISP 3 but produce yellowish–greyish spores on other media and fragment to zig-zag-shaped spore chains with rod-shaped spores that have knobby spore surfaces.
Grows on the surface of liquid media under static conditions but not under shaking conditions.

Acid is produced from l-arabinose, d-fructose, d-galactose, d-glucose, d-mannose, l-rhamnose, trehalose, d-xylose, adonitol, i-erythritol, myo-inositol and d-mannitol, weakly from d-sorbitol but not from cellobiose, maltose, melezitose, methyl α-d-glucoside or sucrose.
Starch is hydrolysed but casein and gelatin are not.
The cell wall contains meso-diaminopimelic acid.
Whole-cell hydrolysate contains galactose and arabinose.
Predominant whole-cell fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0 and iso-C16 : 0.

The type strain, EUM 374T ( = DSM 45351T = ACM 5285T), is an endophytic actinobacterium isolated from the root of a eucalyptus tree, Eucalyptus microcarpa, which was collected from the grounds of the Flinders University campus, Adelaide, South Australia.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 72.9 mol%.
